paragraphs.text:
%md
# About
**Objective:** Become familiar with using Spark MLlib to run Linear Classification on Hadoop
**File locations:** spark-labs/kc_house_data.csv
**Successful outcome:** A trained linear regression model that predicts the price of a house in Kings County, USA
**Before you begin:**
**Related lessons:** Supervised learning, Linear regression

---

paragraphs.title: Retrieve the house dataset and store it in HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%sh

rm -f kc_house_data.csv
wget https://s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/sci-241/house_data/kc_house_data.csv
hdfs dfs -rm spark-labs/kc_house_data.csv
hdfs dfs -put kc_house_data.csv spark-labs/

paragraphs.title: Import libraries
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pyspark.ml.feature import VectorAssembler
from pyspark.ml.regression import LinearRegression
from pyspark.ml.evaluation import RegressionEvaluator
from pyspark.sql.functions import lit

%md
First we need to load the data into a dataframe using the 'header' and 'inferSchema' options.

paragraphs.title: 1 - Load the data into a Spark DataFrame

paragraphs.text:
%md
The data we are working with for this lab represents facts about houses sold in King County, Washington, USA
Our goal is to predict the price they were sold for.
When doing machine learning, it is important to look at the data you are working with
Use z.show(data) to view the first 20 rows of your data

paragraphs.title: 2 - Inspect the data

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Transform the DataFrame into one usable by Spark ML


We are going to create
* a 'features' column containing a vector of the relevant columns of our dataset as well as
* a 'label' column containing the price.

%md

Use the VectorAssembler transformer to assemble those columns ["bedrooms","bathrooms","sqft_living","sqft_lot","floors","grade","yr_built","lat","long","yr_renovated"]
into a single "features" column.

paragraphs.title: 3 - Create the assembler object
4 - Use the assembler to vectorize your data and inspect the new 'features' column

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 5 - Rename the price column to label

paragraphs.text:
%md
To complete this part of the lab, let us review the transformations we have made.

paragraphs.title: 6 - Show the label and features columns

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
This is the data that we will feed to our machine learning algorithm.

%md
Next we need to split this data between a training and a testing set.
We will keep 
* 80% of the rows for training and save the other 20% for testing on and
* use a seed of 101 that will help everyone in the class have similar results.

paragraphs.title: 7 - Split the data into training and test instances
8 - Create an object of the class LinearRegression with the default parameters

paragraphs.text:
%md

Now we can train the model on the training data. This may take a few seconds to run.

paragraphs.title: 9 - Train the model on the training data

paragraphs.text:
%md
Use the trained model to make predictions on the test data by calling the 'transform' transformation of the model on the test data.

paragraphs.title: 10 - Use the model to make predictions

paragraphs.text:
%md
The last dataframe now has an extra prediction column
We can compare the prediction to the actual sale price of a few of the rows in the test set

paragraphs.title: 11 - Check the accuracy of the predictions

paragraphs.text:
%md
Now we are going to use an evaluator with the R2 measure to evaluate the accuracy of our model.

paragraphs.title: 12 - Create an RegressionEvaluator object
13 - Print out the R2 measure

paragraphs.text:
%md

We can use Zeppelin's built in features to visualize our labels and predictions.
1. Copy and paste the code below in the next paragraph 
2. Use the pivot table feature 
3. Choose the scatter plot visualization
4. select 'sqft_living' for the xAxis, 'label' for the yAxis and 'group' for the group.

~~~
p1 = predictions.select(["bedrooms","bathrooms","sqft_living","sqft_lot","floors","grade","yr_built",'yr_renovated','prediction'])
p2 = predictions.select(["bedrooms","bathrooms","sqft_living","sqft_lot","floors","grade","yr_built",'yr_renovated','label'])
p1 = p1.withColumn("group",lit("prediction")).withColumnRenamed('prediction','label')
p2 = p2.withColumn("group",lit("actual"))
toVisualize = p1.union(p2)
z.show(toVisualize)
~~~

paragraphs.title: 14 - Visualize the data
Bonus
paragraphs.text:
%md
If you have extra time, try to improve your model.
* Combine the assembler and regressor into a Pipeline
* Go back to step #4 in the notebook and change the columns included as features
* Try to include some location information
* After editing that cell, run the entire notebook again by hitting the play button at the top

%md
# Result
**You have now:** You have now successfully trained a linear model and evaluated its accuracy.

---

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

p1 = predictions.select(["bedrooms","bathrooms","sqft_living","sqft_lot","floors","grade","yr_built",'yr_renovated','prediction'])
p2 = predictions.select(["bedrooms","bathrooms","sqft_living","sqft_lot","floors","grade","yr_built",'yr_renovated','label'])
p1 = p1.withColumn("group",lit("prediction")).withColumnRenamed('prediction','label')
p2 = p2.withColumn("group",lit("actual"))
toVisualize = p1.union(p2)
z.show(toVisualize)

paragraphs.title: Additional resources
paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.
